character.name: Clara
character.bio: Clara, 38, is a government official specialising in agriculture and food policy. She's known for her diplomatic skills and passion for improving food systems. With a degree in environmental law, Clara has worked in local and international agencies. She believes in stakeholder collaboration to craft policies that benefit both producers and consumers.

intro.text:
I'm working on a comprehensive food policy proposal that will shape the agricultural sector for the next decade. It's a complex challenge with many stakeholders and competing interests. I need to make decisions about sustainability, trade, support for farmers, and consumer choices. What approach do you think works best?

By answering a few questions, you can help me design this policy!

questions.context: Clara says: I usually begin my mornings reviewing proposals. My team is divided between focusing on increasing food security, promoting sustainability and supporting small scale farmers.
questions.text: What role should government play in promoting sustainable farming?

options.A: Rural Support: policies that strongly support small-scale and local farmers to preserve rural livelihoods.
options.B: Balanced Growth: balanced policies that integrate sustainability with economic growth.
options.C: Food Security: policies that focus on maximizing food production to ensure food security for all.

A.title: You chose: rural support
A.text: I place rural resilience and equity at the center. This strengthens local economies but may require extra investment and coordination to scale.

B.title: You chose: balanced growth
B.text: I'm building policies that address both ecological concerns and economic realities. It's a realistic path forward but could lack bold action where needed.

C.title: You chose: food security
C.text: I aim to secure a steady food supply for everyone, prioritizing availability above all. While efficient, this may come at the cost of long-term environmental and social resilience.

questions.context: Clara says: After reviewing I attend a meeting with stakeholders, including farmers, researchers, and private sector representatives. Each group has conflicting priorities.
questions.text: How should government support farmers economically?

options.A: Voice Underrepresented: you advocate for underrepresented groups, ensuring their voices are heard and prioritized.
options.B: Common Ground: you seek common ground, crafting policies that balance diverse stakeholder needs.
options.C: Large Producers: you prioritize the interests of large-scale producers to ensure economic stability.

A.title: You chose: voice underrepresented
A.text: I champion equity in decision-making. This can bring fresh perspectives and justice to policy—but may challenge dominant interests.

B.title: You chose: common ground
B.text: I'm navigating competing priorities with diplomacy. It's a fair, inclusive approach, though reaching consensus may delay urgent decisions.

C.title: You chose: large producers
C.text: I'm safeguarding economic output and stability. This can keep systems running efficiently but may reinforce existing inequalities or environmental issues.

questions.context: Clara says: During a briefing, my advisors present data on the agricultural sector's contribution to climate change. I need to draft a policy response.

options.A: Agroecological Systems: policies that prioritize agroecological systems, even at the expense of lower outputs.
options.B: Climate-Smart: policies promoting climate-smart practices that balance productivity with resilience.
options.C: Intensive High-Yield: policies that encourage intensive, high-yield systems with lower emissions.

A.title: You chose: agroecological systems
A.text: I'm committing to systems that work with nature, not against it. This fosters long-term health but may limit short-term yields and scalability.

B.title: You chose: climate-smart
B.text: I'm taking a forward-looking, balanced approach. It supports productivity and adaptation, though implementation can be complex and uneven.

C.title: You chose: intensive high-yield
C.text: I'm maximising output while cutting emissions—focusing on tech-driven solutions. It's efficient, but may still strain natural resources and ecosystems.

questions.context: Clara says: I attend a parliamentary debate on animal welfare standards. Lobbyists argue for different levels of regulation.
questions.text: How should government protect agricultural land?

options.A: Strict Standards: push for strict animal welfare standards, emphasizing ethics over cost concerns.
options.B: Moderate Standards: advocate for moderate standards that improve welfare without burdening producers.
options.C: Minimal Regulations: support minimal regulations to keep production costs low and food affordable.

A.title: You chose: strict standards
A.text: I'm setting a high ethical bar, protecting animal rights regardless of cost. It leads by example, but could face economic resistance.

B.title: You chose: moderate standards
B.text: I'm advancing animal welfare step by step, balancing compassion with practicality. It's politically viable, though progress may be slow.

C.title: You chose: minimal regulations
C.text: I'm prioritizing cost control and market stability. While effective in keeping food prices low, this overlooks ethical and consumer concerns and might be at the expense of animals and environment.

questions.context: Clara says: At a meeting on biodiversity, you hear proposals ranging from intensive monoculture systems to diverse, low-input systems.
questions.text: What scale of farming should policy support?

options.A: Low-Input Protection: low-input systems that protect biodiversity at all costs.
options.B: Mixed Systems: mixed systems that balance biodiversity with agricultural productivity, their implementation might be more unlikely and difficult for farmers, due to the higher costs.
options.C: High-Yield Efficiency: high-yield systems that prioritize efficiency over biodiversity.

A.title: You chose: low-input protection
A.text: I'm focused on ecological integrity, even if yields drop. It's a nature-first approach that may demand major shifts in consumption and distribution.

B.title: You chose: mixed systems
B.text: I'm promoting innovation that doesn't pit nature against farming. It's complex to implement but supports multiple goals.

C.title: You chose: high-yield efficiency
C.text: I'm working toward maximum output, which can feed more people. Yet, this often means sacrificing ecological health and long-term viability.

questions.context: Clara says: A drought in a neighboring region is disrupting food supplies, I'm asked to propose an emergency response.
questions.text: How strict should animal welfare standards be?

options.A: Self-Sufficient Systems: advocate for long-term investments in sustainable, self-sufficient food systems.
options.B: Local Subsidies: support local farmers with subsidies to build resilience and maintain supply.
options.C: Scale Imports: scale up imports to ensure affordable and consistent food supplies.

A.title: You chose: self-sufficient systems
A.text: I'm rethinking the system to prevent future shocks. It's visionary, but slower to implement, and may require public support for higher costs.

B.title: You chose: local subsidies
B.text: I'm investing in your region's future while responding to crisis. It supports long-term stability, but may not fully meet short-term needs.

C.title: You chose: scale imports
C.text: I'm acting fast to stabilize prices and supply. It's efficient for immediate relief but could entrench global dependencies and emissions.

questions.context: Clara says: In the evening, I'm reviewing a draft policy requiring companies to reduce their environmental footprint, which may increase food prices.
questions.text: Should government promote dietary change toward plant-based options?

options.A: Strong Regulation: push for strong regulation that makes some foods more expensive due to higher sustainability standards.
options.B: Gradual Changes: encourage gradual changes that balance affordability with environmental goals.
options.C: Minimize Costs: minimize costs for companies to keep food prices affordable.

A.title: You chose: strong regulation
A.text: I'm enforcing accountability and pushing systems to evolve. It may raise prices, but puts sustainability front and center

B.title: You chose: gradual changes
B.text: I'm promoting a just transition. It's strategic and balanced, but requires monitoring and adjustment to stay effective.

C.title: You chose: minimize costs
C.text: I'm cautious about placing too much burden on companies or consumers. This maintains accessibility, but could slow environmental progress.

questions.context: Clara says: At the end of the day, I like to reflect. This time I choose to reflect on my vision for the future of agriculture and food systems.
questions.text: What vision should guide long-term food policy?

options.A: Localized Low-Input: a localized, low-input system prioritizing resilience and environmental stewardship.
options.B: Balanced Innovation: a balanced system integrating innovation, sustainability, and stakeholder collaboration.
options.C: Efficient Global: a highly efficient global system focused on affordability and availability.

A.title: You chose: localized low-input
A.text: I imagine a deeply sustainable, community-rooted food future. It's regenerative and values-driven, though harder to scale quickly.

B.title: You chose: balanced innovation
B.text: I see a future built on shared goals and innovation. It's inclusive and adaptable, though may require constant negotiation and leadership.

C.title: You chose: efficient global
C.text: I envision a streamlined, interconnected food system that feeds the world affordably. It's productive, but may be vulnerable to shocks and ethics blind spots.
